EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.0   Introduction

INEOS O&P USA is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for our employees, the public, and the environment.  As part of this commitment, INEOS has established a system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility.  One component of this system is a risk management program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at INEOS and that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's Regulation 40 CFR 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule).  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a summary of the risk management plan (RMP Plan) describing the risk management program at INEOS.  This plan summary is intended to satisfy the RMP Plan requirement of the RMP Rule (40 CFR 68.150 though 40 CFR 68.185) and to provide the public with a description of the risk management plan in place at INEOS.



2.0   Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

INEOS is committed to the welfare of their employees, the public, and to the preservation of the environment.  INEOS implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  In the event of an accidental release, INEOS will conduct emergency response actions to help prevent or minimize injury to the public and the environment.



3.0   Facility Process and Regulated Substances

INEOS manufactures polypropylene resins for a wide variety of industrial and consumer applications such as plastic bottles, chip bags, children's toys, and car parts.

  

The manufacturing process uses propylene as the basic building block for producing polypropylene. Propane is inherent to polypropylene processes.  



4.0   Offsite Consequence Analysis

An offsite consequence analysis was conducted on the polypropylene facility.  The subject analysis consisted of worst-case scenario(s) and alternative release scenario(s).



One worst-case scenario was completed for fl

ammable RMP compounds.  This scenario is a release of propylene from a rupture in the 2 propylene storage vessels and associated piping, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The pressure effects from this scenario could reach the offsite industrial endpoints is not predicted to reach residential populations.



Each worst-case scenario is considered a conservative analysis.  These scenarios are based on stable conditions and low wind speed.  In addition, the worst-case scenarios did not consider any existing safety systems or mitigation activities.



Two ARS were completed for flammable RMP compounds.  The first scenario is a propylene release from the PP metering yard due to a piping failure, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The second scenario is a vapor cloud fire from release of propylene also from the PP metering yard due to a piping failure.  The pressure / thermal effects from these scenarios may reach the offsite industrial endpoints but are not predicted to reach residential populations.



The alternative release scenarios are based on the most common weather conditions.  It should be noted that these scenarios did not consider any existing safety systems or mitigation activities other than emergency response.



5.0   Accident Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The polypropylene process is currently covered by the PSM standard.  As such, a Program Level 3 prevention program is in place.  The following paragraphs describe the prevention program elements at INEOS.



5.1   Safety Information 

INEOS maintains a variety of technical documents that are used to help ensure safe operations of the polypropylene processes.  We review communicate and maintain Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) document the physical properties of all hazardous substances.  The engineering design documents include the operating parameters, the design basis and configuration of the equipment of the covered process, and references to applicable

codes and standards.



5.2   Hazard Review 

INEOS performs and periodically updates hazard reviews of the processes to help identify and control process hazards.  Checklists include items to help ensure that INEOS operates and maintains the equipment in a manner consistent with the applicable design specifications, codes, standards, and regulations.



5.3   Operating Procedures 

INEOS maintains its operating procedures under an ISO9001 and OSHA PSM/VPP programs.  As such we are required to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operation should be performed.  The operating procedures are used to (1) train employees and contractors and (2) serve as reference guides for appropriate actions to take during both normal operations and process upsets.



5.4   Training 

INEOS trains personnel in the operating procedures to help ensure safe and effective performance of their assigned tasks.  A training documentation file is maintained to help ensure that refresher training is provided, as necessary.



5.5   Maintenance 

INEOS properly maintains the process equipment.  The maintenance program includes (1) procedures to safely guide workers in their maintenance tasks, (2) worker training in the maintenance procedures, and (3) an inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deterioration and damage before the equipment fails.



5.6   Management of Change 

INEOS has a program in place to document changes to the process.  A significant change in process chemicals, technology, equipment, practices or procedures prompt implementation of this program.  The program is designed to (1) evaluate the impact of the change on the process, (2) update records on the process and (3) ensure that workers are informed and trained on any significant changes.



5.7   Pre-startup Review 

INEOS performs audits on a new process or an existing process that has undergone a modification affecting the safety information.  This review is

done prior to operating.  The review (1) confirms proper equipment was used, (2) safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are updated, (3) a hazard evaluation has been conducted, and (4) training has been updated.



5.8   Compliance Audits

INEOS performs periodic compliance audits of the covered process to verify that the process is operating in compliance with the Process Safety Management standard.  Compliance audit reports are prepared after each audit, with documented deficiencies and corrections.



5.9   Incident Investigations

INEOS investigates all incidents that could reasonably have resulted in a serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment.  INEOS procedures require an investigation team to be assembled, and the investigation to be initiated within 48 hours of the incident.  The results of the investigation are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate process enhancements are implemented.



5.10   Employee Participation

INEOS requires participation by the affected employees in development (1) of the process hazard evaluation, (2) process safety management, and (3) operating procedures of all covered processes.  The employees that work with or maintain the processes are given access to all information required under the rule.



5.11   Hot Work Permits

INEOS has written safety practices in place for fire protection and process operation.  A permitting system is used to prevent any unsafe acts on or around the covered process.



5.12   Contractors

INEOS reviews all contractors prior to working on or near a covered process.  The contractor must submit information that indicates the work can be performed competently and safely.  The company will provide information on the hazards of the process and the safety practices in place.  Documents are kept to confirm that the information was received and understood.  In addition, Innovene has procedures in place, which require the entrance, presence, and exit of

contractors to be controlled.



5.13   Chemical-specific Prevention Steps

In addition to engineering review and hazard analyses previously mentioned, workers who perform operations involving RMP listed compounds receive training emphasizing safe handling procedures developed by INEOS.  In addition, several equipment safeguards are in place.  Examples of such safeguards include: hydrocarbon detection and water deluge systems, related piping and vessel periodic inspection and maintenance, and continuous process monitoring for operations involving RMP listed compounds.

  

6.0   Five-Year Accident History

INEOS maintains a 5-year accident history that fulfills the requirements of the RMP rule (A?68.42).  This history indicates a good record of accidental release prevention.  No releases of regulated substances have occurred from Innovene during the subject five year period that resulted in consequences of interest (i.e., deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site; or known deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage off site).



7.0 Emergency Response Program

INEOS has established a written emergency response plan that complies with the RMP rule and with other federal contingency plan regulations.  This plan has been communicated to local emergency response officials through the local fire department.  Regular dialogue is maintained between the facility and the local response personnel, and the company provides appropriate information to the fire chief.  INEOS periodically conducts emergency response drills, including annual drills coordinated with the local response authorities.

 

8.0 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Planned changes to improve safety are described in INEOS Process Hazard Analyses, plant alterations, projects, and the Site Safety, Health & Security Plan.
